Company markets, manufactures and sells:\n¬∑ beverage concentrates, sometimes referred to as ‚Äúbeverage bases,‚Äù and syrups, including fountain syrups (we refer to this part of our business as our ‚Äúconcentrate\noperations"); and\n¬∑ finished sparkling soft drinks and other beverages (we refer to this part of our business as our ‚Äúfinished product operations").\nGenerally, finished product operations generate higher net operating revenues but lower gross profit margins than concentrate operations.\nOur concentrate operations typically generate net operating revenues by selling concentrates, syrups and certain finished beverages to authorized bottling operations (to which\nwe typically refer as our bottlers‚Äù? or our bottling partners"). Our bottling partners either combine concentrates with still or sparkling water and sweeteners (depending on the\nproduct), or combine syrups with still or sparkling water, to produce finished beverages. The finished beverages are packaged in authorized containers, such as cans and\nrefillable and nonrefilable glass and plastic bottles, bearing our trademarks or trademarks licensed to us and are then sold to retailers directly or, in some cases, through\nwholesalers or other bottlers. In addition, outside the United States, our bottling partners are typically authorized to manufacture fountain syrups, using our concentrates, which\nthey sell to fountain retailers for use in 968316b0726df02b]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=0fb7ce83e6f911f0ba989af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nForeignCurrencyRisk\nIn general, the Company is a net receiver of currencies other than the U.S. dollar. Accordingly, changes in exchange rates, and in particular a strengthening of\nthe U.S. dollar, will negatively affect the Company\'s net sales and gross margins as expressed in U.S. dollars. There is a risk that the Company will have to\nadjust local currency pricing due to competitive pressures when there has been significant volatility in foreign currency exchange rates.\nThe Company may enter into foreign currency forward and option contracts with financial institutions to protect against foreign exchange risks associated with\ncertain existing assets and liabilities, certain firmly committed transactions, forecasted future cash flows and net investments in foreign subsidiaries. In addition,\nthe Company has entered, and in the future may enter, into foreign currency contracts to partially offset the foreign currency exchange gains and losses on its\nforeign currency-denominated debt issuances. The Company generally hedges portions of its forecasted foreign currency exposure associated with revenue\nand inventory purchases, typically for up to 12 months. However, the Company may choose not to hedge certain foreign exchange exposures for a variety of\nreasons including, but not limited to, accounting considerations or the prohibitive economic cost of hedging particular exposures.\nApple Inc. | 2021 Form 10-K | 26\nTo provide an assessment of the foreign currency risk associated with\n\n\n--- Chunk 5 (Relevance: 0.46) ---\n[Document: COCACOLA_2021_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: d7210e1c1d56dc3c]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=134a6c56e6f911f0b2579af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nGrossProfitMargin\nGross profit margin is a ratio calculated by dividing gross profit by net operating revenues. Management believes gross profit margin provides investors with useful information\nrelated to the profitability of our business prior to considering all of the operating costs incurred. Management uses this measure in making financial, operating and planning\ndecisions and in evaluating the Company\'s performance.\nOur gross profit margin increased to 60.3 percent in 2021 from 59.3 percent in 2020. This increase was primarily due to the impact of favorable pricing initiatives and favorable\nchannel and package mix as well as the gradual recovery in away-from-home channels in many markets throughout 2021, partially offset by the impact of increased commodity\nand transportation\ncosts. We expect commodity and transportation costs to continue to increase in 2022, and we will continue to proactively take actions in an effort to mitigate the impact of these\nincremental costs.\nSelling,GeneralandAdministrativeExpenses\nThe following table sets forth the components of selling, general and administrative expenses (in millions):\nSelling, general and administrative expenses increased $2,413 million, or 25 percent, in 2021. This increase was primarily due to higher annual incentive and stock-based\ncompensation expense, increased charitable donations and increased marketing spending, which was reduced in 2020 as a result of uncertainties associated with the COVID-19\npandemic. The CoviD-19\npandemic has at times significantly curtailed global economic activity and caused significant volatility and disruption in global financial markets. The COviD-19\npandemic and the measures taken by many countries in response have affected and could in the future materially impact the Company\'s business, results of\noperations and financial condition, as well as the price of the Company\'s stock.\nDuring 2021, aspects of the Company\'s business continued to be affected by the COviD-19 pandemic, with many of the Company\'s retail stores, as well as\nchannel partner points of sale, temporarily closed at various times, and a significant number of the Company\'s employees working remotely. The Company has\nreopened all of its retail stores and substantially all of its other facilities, subject to operating restrictions to protect public health and the health and safety of\nemployees and customers, and it continues to work on safely reopening the remainder of its facilities, subject to local rules and regulations. In addition, the Company\'s\nglobal supply chain is large and complex and a majority of the Company\'s supplier facilities, including manufacturing and assembly sites, are located outside the\nU.S. As a result, the Company\'s operations and performance depend significantly on global and regional economic conditions.\nAdverse macroeconomic conditions, including inflation, slower growth or recession, new or increased tariffs and other barriers to trade, changes to fiscal and\nmonetary policy, tighter credit, higher interest rates, high unemployment and currency fluctuations can materially adversely affect demand for the Company\'s\nproducts and services. The Company also accrues necessary cancellation fee reserves for orders of excess products and components. The Company\nreviews long-lived assets, including capital assets held at its suppliers\' facilities and inventory prepayments, for impairment whenever events or circumstances\nindicate the assets may not be recoverable. If the Company determines that an impairment has occurred, it records a write-down equal to the amount by which\nthe carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair value. Although the Company believes its inventory, capital assets, inventory prepayments and other assets and\npurchase commitments are currently recoverable, there can be no assurance the Company will not incur write-downs, fees, impairments and other charges\ngiven the rapid and unpredictable pace of product obsolescence in the industries in which the Company competes.\nThe Company orders components for its products and builds inventory in advance of product announcements and shipments. Manufacturing purchase\nobligations cover the Company\'s forecasted component and manufacturing requirements, typically for periods up to 150 days. The widening gap between price and all MAs suggests potential for pullback to reestablish equilibrium..."\n   - Example for downtrend: "Price is -14% below MA(200), -10% below MA(50), and -5% below MA(20), confirming a persistent downtrend across all timeframes. The consistent negative distances indicate structural bearish pressure..."\n\n2. **Indicator Tension Analysis:**\n   - Analyze CONFLICT or ALIGNMENT between:\n     * Momentum indicators (RSI, BB position)\n     * Multi-period trend structure (MA20/MA50/MA200 relationships)\n   - Example: "RSI at 37 approaching oversold, creating tension with price -14% below MA(200). Short-term momentum suggests bounce potential, but multi-period trend structure (all MAs in bearish configuration) indicates structural resistance..."\n\n3. **Dead Cat Bounce vs. Value Entry (Multi-Period Assessment):**\n   - Use multi-period MA distances to categorize:\n     * Dead Cat Bounce Risk: Price significantly below MA20/MA50/MA200 with no bullish crossover signals\n     * Value Entry Opportunity: Price near key MAs with structural support alignment\n   - Provide reasoning based on API-derived MA distances only\n\n4. **Pivot Zones (API-Derived Levels Only):**\n   - Use ONLY the API-provided MA levels and BB levels\n   - Example: {"ma200_level": 55.84, "ma50_level": 56.09, "ma20_level": 58.09, "bb_middle": 58.09}\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n  "market_regime": "<Long-form structural description (3-5 sentences) analyzing short/medium/long-term trend interplay. MUST identify mean reversion risks when price significantly deviates from MAs. Use API-derived distances only.>",\n  "indicator_tension_analysis": "<Qualitative analysis of conflict/alignment between momentum (RSI/BB) and multi-period trend structure (MA20/MA50/MA200). 2-3 sentences.>",\n  "dead_cat_vs_value": "<Structural categorization as \'Dead Cat Bounce Risk\' or \'Value Entry Opportunity\' with multi-period MA distance reasoning. 2-3 sentences. NO trade recommendations.>",\n  "pivot_zones": {\n    "ma200_level": 55.84,\n    "ma50_level": 56.09,\n    "ma20_level": 58.09,\n    "bb_middle": 58.09\n  }\n}\n\nCRITICAL: You are providing PURE DESCRIPTIVE EVIDENCE using API-derived metrics ONLY. No numeric signals, no LLM-generated scores, only qualitative structural analysis.'}]

Premium segment showing resilience despite macro concerns.",\n       "Macro_Environment": "Headwinds from inflation and supply chain disruptions mentioned across multiple reports. Management cited elevated input costs as margin pressure.",\n       "Management_Confidence": "Cautious guidance with management citing \'uncertain macro backdrop.\' Forward revenue outlook lowered by 3-5% for next quarter.",\n       "Competitive_Position": "Market share gains in services segment noted by analysts. However, smartphone market share faces pressure from competitors in China."\n     }\n\n3. **Causal Narrative (BECAUSE-THEN Logic):**\n   - Synthesize a coherent narrative paragraph (3-5 sentences) using explicit BECAUSE-THEN logic\n   - Connect segment drivers to overall performance causally\n   - Example: "Revenue grew 8% YoY BECAUSE iPhone sales rebounded 10%, WHICH THEN compensated for services growth slowdown. DUE TO inflation pressures, management focused on premium models, WHICH LED TO sustained margins despite volume concerns."\n   - This MUST read like a professional analyst\'s narrative, NOT bullet points\n\n4. **Expectation Gap Analysis (Qualitative):**\n   - Describe "Actual Performance vs. Market Expectations" qualitatively\n   - Identify beats, misses, or inline results with market reaction context\n   - Example: "Revenue beat consensus by 2%, BUT stock fell 3% BECAUSE guidance was cut 5%, revealing investor focus shifted from current quarter to future outlook. Market reaction suggests disappointing forward outlook overshadowed current beat."\n\n5. **Paradoxes and Tensions:**\n   - Identify anomalies: "Good News, Price Drop" or "Revenue Beat, Weak Guidance"\n   - Explain what these contradictions reveal about business health\n   - Example: "Paradox: Strong earnings BUT weak stock reaction. Reflects investor concern that growth is price-driven (unsustainable) rather than volume-driven."\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n    "qualitative_sentiment_assessment": "<Descriptive overall sentiment (1-2 sentences). NO numeric scores.>",\n    "events": ["EVENT_TYPE_1", "EVENT_TYPE_2"],\n    "keywords": ["keyword1", "keyword2", "keyword3", "keyword4", "keyword5"],\n    "news_summary": "<Coherent narrative paragraph using BECAUSE-THEN causal logic (3-5 sentences, NOT bullet points)>",\n    "sentiment_matrix": {\n        "Product_Demand": "<Qualitative audit of demand signals from news. 1-2 sentences.>",\n        "Macro_Environment": "<Qualitative audit of macro headwind/tailwind narratives. 1-2 sentences.>",\n        "Management_Confidence": "<Qualitative audit of guidance tone and management commentary. 1-2 sentences.>",\n        "Competitive_Position": "<Qualitative audit of market share and competitive dynamics. 1-2 sentences.>"\n    },\n    "causal_narrative": "<Deep causal explanation connecting segment drivers to performance with BECAUSE-THEN logic. 2-3 sentences.>",\n    "expectation_gap": "<Qualitative analysis of actual vs. expected performance with market reaction. 2-3 sentences.>",\n    "paradoxes_or_tensions": "<Contradictions and what they reveal about business health. 1-2 sentences or \'None identified\'.>"\n}\n\n**Event Types:** EARNINGS_CALL, PRODUCT_LAUNCH, REGULATORY_ACTION, ANALYST_UPGRADE, MACRO_ECONOMIC, NONE\n\nCRITICAL: This is PURE DESCRIPTIVE EVIDENCE. Shipping and handling costs incurred to move goods from our manufacturing locations or sales distribution centers to our customers\nare also included in the line itm cost of goods sold in ur consolidated statement of income, xcept for costs incurred todistribute goods sold by ur consolidated botlers to\nour customers, which are included in the line item selling, general and administrative expenses in our consolidated statement of income. Our customers generally do not pay us\nseparately for shipping and handling costs. We recognize the cost of shipping and handling activities that are performed after a customer obtains control of the goods as costs to\nfulfill our promise to provide goods to the customer. As a result of this election, the Company does not evaluate whether shipping and handling activities are services promised\nto customers. Our bottling partners either combine concentrates with still or sparkling water and sweeteners (depending on the\nproduct), or combine syrups with still or sparkling water, to produce finished beverages. The effects of the remeasurement of these\nassets and liabilities are partially offset by the impact of our economic hedging program for certain exposures on our consolidated balance sheet. Shipping and handling costs incurred to move goods from our manufacturing locations or sales distribution centers to our customers\nare also included in the line itm cost of goods sold in ur consolidated statement of income, xcept for costs incurred todistribute goods sold by ur consolidated botlers to\nour customers, which are included in the line item selling, general and administrative expenses in our consolidated statement of income. Our customers generally do not pay us\nseparately for shipping and handling costs. We recognize the cost of shipping and handling activities that are performed after a customer obtains control of the goods as costs to\nfulfill our promise to provide goods to the customer. As a result of this election, the Company does not evaluate whether shipping and handling activities are services promised\nto customers. If revenue is recognized for the related goods before the shipping and handling activities occur, the related costs of those shipping and handling activities are\naccrued.\nSales,Use,Value-Added and ExciseTaxes\nThe Company collects taxes imposed directly on its customers related to sales, use, value-added, excise and other similar taxes. Our recovery has been asynchronous and the full extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will affect our results of operations,\nfinancial condition and cash flows will depend on future developments that are highly uncertain and cannot be predicted, including, among others, new information which may\nemerge concerning the pandemic, vaccine adoption rates (including boosters) and the effectiveness of vaccines in limiting or stopping the spread of COVID-19, either over the\nlong term or against new, emerging variants of COVID-19, and any related actions by governments.\nThe extent and nature of government actions related to the COVID-19 pandemic varied throughout 2020 and 2021 based upon the then-current extent and severity of the\nCOVID-19 pandemic within the respective markets. At times we experienced a decrease in sales of certain of our products in markets around the world, including consumer\ndemand shifting to more at-home consumption versus away-from-home consumption. While in 2021 we have experienced improved trends in away-from-home channels and\nimproved margins, if COVID-19 infection rates i\n\n\n--- Chunk 2 (Relevance: 0.44) ---\n[Document: COCACOLA_2021_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: b708fce87cca2d7f]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=134a6c56e6f911f0b2579af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nProductSafetyandQuality\nWe strive to meet the highest standards in both product safety and product quality. We are aware that some consumers have concerns and negative viewpoints regarding certain\ningredients used in our products. The Coca-Cola system works every day to share safe and refreshing beverages with consumers around the world. We have rigorous product\nand ingredient safety and quality standards designed to ensure safety and quality in each of our products, and we drive innovation that provides new beverage options to satisfy\nconsumers? evolving needs and preferences.\nWe work to ensure consistent safety and quality through strong governance and compliance with applicable regulations and standards. We stay current with new regulations,\nindustry best practices and marketplace conditions, and we engage with standard-setting and industry organizations. Additionally, we manufacture and distribute our products\naccording to strict policies, requirements and specifications set forth in an integrated quality management program that continually measures all operations within the Coca-\nCola system against the same stringent standards. Our quality management program also identifies and mitigates risks and drives improvement. We own or license and market numerous beverage brands, which we group into the following categories: Trademark Coca-Cola; sparkling flavors;\nwater, sports, coffee and tea; juice, value-added dairy and plant-based beverages; and emerging beverages. We own and market five of the world\'s top six nonalcoholic\nsparkling soft drink brands: Coca-Cola, Sprite, Fanta, Coca-Cola Zero Sugar and Diet Coke/Coca-Cola Light.\nWe make our branded beverage products available to consumers throughout the world through our network of independent bottling partners, distributors, wholesalers and\nretailers as well as the Company\'s consolidated bottling and distribution operations. Verify it belongs to KO:\n- If auditing KO, and the chunk discusses a different entity (e.g. Coca-Cola vs Apple), IGNORE it.\n- DATA CROSS-CONTAMINATION IS A TERMINATION OFFENSE.\n\n**2. TABLE ANCHORING (ELIMINATING DATA_GAP):**\nSearch specifically for these anchors in the chunks to find missing metrics:\n- Revenue: "Consolidated Statements of Operations", "Net Sales", "Net Operating Revenues".\n- Cash Flow: "Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows", "Net cash provided by operating activities".\n- Profitability: "Gross Margin", "Operating Income".\nReconstruct the full table logic if values are split across chunks.\n\n**3. SOURCE TRACEABILITY:**\n- You MUST provide the exact **Document Name** (e.g. APPLE_2022_10K.pdf) and **Chunk ID** for every metric.\n- This information is provided at the start of each chunk.\n\n=== EXTRACTION TASK ===\n\n**1. Revenue Performance**:\n   - value: Raw metric (e.g., "$394.3B, +8% YoY")\n   - analysis: BECAUSE-THEN causal logic explaining segment drivers.\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the Top 1 source chunk (tables converted to Markdown format).\n   - source_link: Construct a reference: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from the chunk metadata (for clickable PDF preview).\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score from chunk metadata.\n\n**2. Profitability Audit**:\n   - value: Gross/Operating margins.\n   - analysis: BECAUSE-THEN logic (e.g., "Margin dropped BECAUSE of FX headwinds").\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the source chunk.\n   - source_link: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from chunk metadata.\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score.\n\n**3. Cash Flow Stability**:\n   - value: "Net cash provided by operating activities" (Operating Cash Flow).\n   - analysis: Assessment of cash generation sustainability using BECAUSE-THEN logic.\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the source chunk.\n   - source_link: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from chunk metadata.\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score.\n\n**4. Management Guidance & Risks**:\n   - Audit tone and specific projections.\n   - List 3-5 structural risks with specific impacts and source citations.\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n    "ticker": "KO",\n    "revenue_performance": {\n        "value": "string",\n        "analysis": "string",\n        "evidence_md": "string (Markdown-cleaned chunk text)",\n        "source_link": "DocumentName | ID",\n        "source_url": "string (clickable RAGFlow URL)",\n        "metadata": {"page_num": int, "relevance_score": float}\n    },\n    "profitability_audit": {\n        "value": "string",\n        "analysis": "string",\n        "evidence_md": "string (Markdown-cleaned chunk text)",\n        "source_link": "DocumentName | ID",\n        "source_url": "string (clickable RAGFlow URL)",\n        "metadata": {"page_num": int, "relevance_score": float}\n    },\n    "cash_flow_stability": {\n        "value": "string",\n        "analysis": "string",\n        "evidence_md": "string (Markdown-cleaned chunk text)",\n        "source_link": "DocumentName | ID",\n        "source_url": "string (clickable RAGFlow URL)",\n        "metadata": {"page_num": int, "relevance_score": float}\n    },\n    "management_guidance_audit": "string",\n    "key_risks_evidence": ["string (Risk | Impact | Source)"]\n}\n\nCRITICAL: Provide ONLY the JSON. Research\n\nCategories  [AlphaGraphs](https://news.alphastreet.com/infographics/), [Consumer](https://news.alphastreet.com/consumer-stocks/), [Earnings](https://news.alphastreet.com/earnings/)\n\n# KO Earnings: All you need to know about Coca-Cola‚Äôs Q4 2022 earnings results\n\n##### \n\nThe Coca-Cola Company ([NYSE: KO](https://news.alphastreet.com/symbol/ko/))\xa0reported fourth quarter 2022 earnings results today.\n\nNet revenues grew 7% year-over-year to $10.1 billion. Organic revenues grew 15%.\n\n![](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/Coca-Cola-Q4-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n![](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/Coca-Cola-Q4-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n\nNet income attributable to shareowners of The Coca-Cola Company fell 16% to $2 billion, or $0.47 per share, compared to last year. Comparable EPS was even at $0.45.\n\nRevenue beat expectations while earnings were in line with estimates.\n\nFor the full year of 2023, the company expects to deliver organic revenue growth of 7-8%.\n\n## Prior performance\n\n![Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n![Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n\n### *R\n\n\n=== YOUR PURE DESCRIPTIVE ANALYSIS TASK ===\nCRITICAL RULES:\n- You are providing QUALITATIVE CAUSAL ANALYSIS ONLY\n- DO NOT generate numeric sentiment scores\n- ALL sentiment assessment must be DESCRIPTIVE (e.g., "Broadly positive", "Mixed with bearish undertones", "Decisively negative")\n- Focus on CAUSAL STRUCTURES and STRUCTURAL EVIDENCE from news content\n\n**Critical Analysis Requirements:**\n\n1. **Qualitative Sentiment Assessment:**\n   - Provide a descriptive overall sentiment assessment (1-2 sentences)\n   - Example: "Broadly positive sentiment driven by strong product demand signals, though tempered by macro headwinds and cautious guidance."\n   - NO numeric scores - purely qualitative\n\n2. **Sentiment Matrix (Qualitative Audits for Each Dimension):**\n   - Break down sentiment into sub-factor QUALITATIVE AUDITS (NOT numeric scores):\n     * Product_Demand: Qualitative assessment of customer demand signals from news\n     * Macro_Environment: Qualitative assessment of macro headwind/tailwind narratives\n     * Management_Confidence: Qualitative assessment of guidance tone and management commentary\n     * Competitive_Position: Qualitative assessment of market share and competitive dynamics\n   - Example: {\n       "Product_Demand": "Strong iPhone sales momentum indicated by multiple channel checks and bullish analyst commentary. Premium segment showing resilience despite macro concerns.",\n       "Macro_Environment": "Headwinds from inflation and supply chain disruptions mentioned across multiple reports. Management cited elevated input costs as margin pressure.",\n       "Management_Confidence": "Cautious guidance with management citing \'uncertain macro backdrop.\' Forward revenue outlook lowered by 3-5% for next quarter.",\n       "Competitive_Position": "Market share gains in services segment noted by analysts. However, smartphone market share faces pressure from competitors in China."\n     }\n\n3. **Causal Narrative (BECAUSE-THEN Logic):**\n   - Synthesize a coherent narrative paragraph (3-5 sentences) using explicit BECAUSE-THEN logic\n   - Connect segment drivers to overall performance causally\n   - Example: "Revenue grew 8% YoY BECAUSE iPhone sales rebounded 10%, WHICH THEN compensated for services growth slowdown. DUE TO inflation pressures, management focused on premium models, WHICH LED TO sustained margins despite volume concerns."\n   - This MUST read like a professional analyst\'s narrative, NOT bullet points\n\n4. **Expectation Gap Analysis (Qualitative):**\n   - Describe "Actual Performance vs. Market Expectations" qualitatively\n   - Identify beats, misses, or inline results with market reaction context\n   - Example: "Revenue beat consensus by 2%, BUT stock fell 3% BECAUSE guidance was cut 5%, revealing investor focus shifted from current quarter to future outlook. Market reaction suggests disappointing forward outlook overshadowed current beat."\n\n5. **Paradoxes and Tensions:**\n   - Identify anomalies: "Good News, Price Drop" or "Revenue Beat, Weak Guidance"\n   - Explain what these contradictions reveal about business health\n   - Example: "Paradox: Strong earnings BUT weak stock reaction. Reflects investor concern that growth is price-driven (unsustainable) rather than volume-driven."\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n    "qualitative_sentiment_assessment": "<Descriptive overall sentiment (1-2 sentences). Shipping and handling costs incurred to move goods from our manufacturing locations or sales distribution centers to our customers\nare also included in the line itm cost of goods sold in ur consolidated statement of income, xcept for costs incurred todistribute goods sold by ur consolidated botlers to\nour customers, which are included in the line item selling, general and administrative expenses in our consolidated statement of income. Our customers generally do not pay us\nseparately for shipping and handling costs. We recognize the cost of shipping and handling activities that are performed after a customer obtains control of the goods as costs to\nfulfill our promise to provide goods to the customer. We own or license and market numerous beverage brands, which we group into the following categories: Trademark Coca-Cola; sparkling flavors;\nwater, sports, coffee and tea; juice, value-added dairy and plant-based beverages; and emerging beverages. We own and market five of the world\'s top six nonalcoholic\nsparkling soft drink brands: Coca-Cola, Sprite, Fanta, Coca-Cola Zero Sugar and Diet Coke/Coca-Cola Light.\nWe make our branded beverage products available to consumers throughout the world through our network of independent bottling partners, distributors, wholesalers and\nretailers as well as the Company\'s consolidated bottling and distribution operations. Beverages bearing trademarks owned by or licensed to us account for 2.2 billion of the\nestimated 64 billion servings of all beverages consumed worldwide every day\nWe believe our success depends on our ability to connect with consumers by providing them with a wide variety of beverage options to meet their desires, needs and lifestyles.\nOur success further depends on the ability of our people to execute effectively, every day.\nOur Company markets, manufactures and sells:\n¬∑ beverage concentrates, sometimes referred to as *beverage bases,‚Äù and syrups, including fountain syrups (we refer to this part of our business as\n\n\n--- Chunk 3 (Relevance: 0.54) ---\n[Document: COCACOLA_2022_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: d5d9f1c2ca76f9d6]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=137bd635e6f911f09f8f9af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nNOTE3:NETOPERATINGREVENUES\nOur Company markets, manufactures and sells:\n¬∑ beverage concentrates, sometimes refered to as *beverage bases,‚Äù and syrups, including fountain syrups (we refer to this part of our business as our ‚Äúconcentrate\noperations"); and\n¬∑ finished sparkling soft drinks and other beverages (we refer to this part of our business as our ‚Äúfinished product operations").\nGenerally, finished product operations generate higher net operating revenues but lower gross profit margins than concentrate operations.\nOur concentrate operations typically generate net operating revenues by selling concentrates, syrups and certain finished beverages to authorized bottling operations (to which\nwe typically refer as our ‚Äúbottlers‚Äù or our *"bottling partners"). Our bottling partners either combine concentrates with still or sparkling water and sweeteners (depending on the\nproduct), or combine syrups with still or sparkling water, to produce finished beverages. The finished beverages are packaged in authorized containers, such as cans and\nrefillable and nonrefillable glass and plastic bottles, bearing our trademarks or trademarks licensed to us and are then sold to retalers directly or, in some cases, through\nwholesalers or other botlers. We received net cash proceeds of $228 million and recognized a net gain of $153 million as a result of the refranchising. Also included\nwas the sale of our ownership interest in one of our equity method investees, for which we received cash proceeds of $123 million and recognized a net gain of $13 million.\nDuring 2021, proceeds from disposals of businesses, equity method investments and nonmarketable securities totaled $2,180 million, which primarily related to the sale of our\nownership interest in Coca-Cola Amatil Limited (*CCA"), an equity method investee, to Coca-Cola Europacific Partners plc ("CCEP"), also an equity method investee. The Company had\n$453 million, $391 million and $201 million in interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits accrued as of December 31, 2021, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Of\nthese amounts, expense of $62 million, $190 million and $11 million was recognized in 2021, 2020 and 2019, respectively If the Company were to prevail on all uncertain tax\npositions, the reversal of this accrual would be a benefit to the Company\'s effective tax rate.\nIt is expected that the amount of unrecognized tax benefits will change in the next 12 months; however, we do not expect any changes will have a significant impact on our\nconsolidated statement of income or consolidated balance sheet. These changes may be the result of settlements of ongoing audits, statute of limitations expiring or final\nsettlements in transfer pricing matters that are the subject of litigation. Currently, an estimate of the range of the reasonably possible outcomes cannot be made.\nAs of December 31, 2021, we had $2,313 million of loss carryforwards av\n\n\n=== MARGIN AND COST ANALYSIS ===\n\n--- Chunk 1 (Relevance: 0.59) ---\n[Document: COCACOLA_2022_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: e81e19a97be65ef3]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=137bd635e6f911f09f8f9af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nOURBUSINESS\nGeneral\nThe Coca-Cola Company is a total beverage company, and beverage products bearing our trademarks, sold in the United States since 1886, are now sold in more than 200\ncountries and territories. We own or license and market numerous beverage brands, which we group into the following categories: Trademark Coca-Cola; sparkling flavors;\nwater, sports, coffee and tea; juice, value-added dairy and plant-based beverages; and emerging beverages. We own and market five of the world\'s top six nonalcoholic\nsparkling soft drink brands: Coca-Cola, Sprite, Fanta, Coca-Cola Zero Sugar and Diet Coke/Coca-Cola Light.\nWe make our branded beverage products available to consumers throughout the world through our network of independent bottling partners, distributors, wholesalers and\nretailers as well as the Company\'s consolidated bottling and distribution operations. Shipping and handling costs incurred to move goods from our manufacturing locations or sales distribution centers to our customers\nare also included in the line itm cost of goods sold in ur consolidated statement of income, xcept for costs incurred todistribute goods sold by ur consolidated botlers to\nour customers, which are included in the line item selling, general and administrative expenses in our consolidated statement of income. Our customers generally do not pay us\nseparately for shipping and handling costs. We recognize the cost of shipping and handling activities that are performed after a customer obtains control of the goods as costs to\nfulfill our promise to provide goods to the customer. As a result of this election, the Company does not evaluate whether shipping and handling activities are services promised\nto customers. If revenue is recognized for the related goods before the shipping and handling activities occur, the related costs of those shipping and handling activities are\naccrued.\nSales,Use,Value-Added and ExciseTaxes\nThe Company collects taxes imposed directly on its customers related to sales, use, value-added, excise and other similar taxes. In general, we are self-insured for large portions of many\ndifferent types of claims; however, we do use commercial insurance above our self-insured retentions to reduce the Company\'s risk of catastrophic loss. Our reserves for the\nCompany\'s self-insured losses are estimated using actuarial methods and assumptions of the insurance industry, adjusted for our specific expectations based on our claims\nhistory. Our self-insurance reserves totaled $199 million and $229 million as of December 31, 2022 and 2021, respectively.\nNOTE12:STOCK-BASEDCOMPENSATIONPLANS\nOur Company grants long-term equity awards under its stock-based compensation plans to certain employees of the Company. The Coca-Cola Company 2014 Equity Plan\n("2014 Equity Plan") was approved by shareowners in April 2014. Under the 2014 Equity Plan, a maximum of 500 million shares of our common stock was approved to be\nissued through the grant of equity awards. The 2014 Equity Plan allows for grants of stock options, performance share units, restricted stock, restricted stock units and other\nspecified award types, including cash awards with performance-based vesting criteria. As of December 31, 2022, there were 308 million shares available to be granted under\nthe 2014 Equity Plan. Our recovery has been asynchronous and the full extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will affect our results of operations,\nfinancial condition and cash flows will depend on future developments that are highly uncertain and cannot be predicted, including, among others, new information which may\nemerge concerning the pandemic, vaccine adoption rates (including boosters) and the effectiveness of vaccines in limiting or stopping the spread of COVID-19, either over the\nlong term or against new, emerging variants of COVID-19, and any related actions by governments.\nThe extent and nature of government actions related to the COVID-19 pandemic varied throughout 2020 and 2021 based upon the then-current extent and severity of the\nCOVID-19 pandemic within the respective markets. We are aware that some consumers have concerns and negative viewpoints regarding certain\ningredients used in our products. The Coca-Cola system works every day to share safe and refreshing beverages with consumers around the world. We have rigorous product\nand ingredient safety and quality standards designed to ensure safety and quality in each of our products, and we drive innovation that provides new beverage options to satisfy\nconsumers? evolving needs and preferences.\nWe work to ensure consistent safety and quality through strong governance and compliance with applicable regulations and standards. We stay current with new regulations,\nindustry best practices and marketplace conditions, and we engage with standard-setting and industry organizations. Additionally, we manufacture and distribute our products\naccording to strict policies, requirements and specifications set forth in an integrated quality management program that continually measures all operations within the Coca-\nCola system against the same stringent standards. The company‚Äôs earnings have climbed at a rate of 8.1% per year over the past five years, and future earnings are projected to rise about 5.2% per year. This alignment suggests a balanced momentum environment. Company markets, manufactures and sells:\n¬∑ beverage concentrates, sometimes referred to as ‚Äúbeverage bases,‚Äù and syrups, including fountain syrups (we refer to this part of our business as our ‚Äúconcentrate\noperations"); and\n¬∑ finished sparkling soft drinks and other beverages (we refer to this part of our business as our ‚Äúfinished product operations").\nGenerally, finished product operations generate higher net operating revenues but lower gross profit margins than concentrate operations.\nOur concentrate operations typically generate net operating revenues by selling concentrates, syrups and certain finished beverages to authorized bottling operations (to which\nwe typically refer as our bottlers‚Äù? or our bottling partners"). Our bottling partners either combine concentrates with still or sparkling water and sweeteners (depending on the\nproduct), or combine syrups with still or sparkling water, to produce finished beverages. The finished beverages are packaged in authorized containers, such as cans and\nrefillable and nonrefilable glass and plastic bottles, bearing our trademarks or trademarks licensed to us and are then sold to retailers directly or, in some cases, through\nwholesalers or other bottlers. In addition, outside the United States, our bottling partners are typically authorized to manufacture fountain syrups, using our concentrates, which\nthey sell to fountain retailers for use in None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=0fb7ce83e6f911f0ba989af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nForeignCurrencyRisk\nIn general, the Company is a net receiver of currencies other than the U.S. dollar. Accordingly, changes in exchange rates, and in particular a strengthening of\nthe U.S. dollar, will negatively affect the Company\'s net sales and gross margins as expressed in U.S. dollars. There is a risk that the Company will have to\nadjust local currency pricing due to competitive pressures when there has been significant volatility in foreign currency exchange rates.\nThe Company may enter into foreign currency forward and option contracts with financial institutions to protect against foreign exchange risks associated with\ncertain existing assets and liabilities, certain firmly committed transactions, forecasted future cash flows and net investments in foreign subsidiaries. In addition,\nthe Company has entered, and in the future may enter, into foreign currency contracts to partially offset the foreign currency exchange gains and losses on its\nforeign currency-denominated debt issuances. The Company generally hedges portions of its forecasted foreign currency exposure associated with revenue\nand inventory purchases, typically for up to 12 months. However, the Company may choose not to hedge certain foreign exchange exposures for a variety of\nreasons including, but not limited to, accounting considerations or the prohibitive economic cost of hedging particular exposures.\nApple Inc. | 2021 Form 10-K | 26\nTo provide an assessment of the foreign currency risk associated with\n\n\n--- Chunk 4 (Relevance: 0.43) ---\n[Document: 2335c96e6f7562d0]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=0fb7ce83e6f911f0ba989af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nFinancialRisks\nThe Company expects its quarterly net sales and results of operations to fluctuate.\nThe Company\'s profit margins vary across its products, services, geographic segments and distribution channels. For example, the gross margins on the\nCompany\'s products and services vary significantly and can change over time. The Company\'s gross margins are subject to volatility and downward pressure\ndue to a variety of factors, including: continued industry-wide global product pricing pressures and product pricing actions that the Company may take in\nresponse to such pressures; increased competition; the Company\'s ability to effectively stimulate demand for certain of its products and services; compressed\nproduct life cycles; potential increases in the cost of components, outside manufacturing services, and developing, acquiring and delivering content for the\nCompany\'s services; the Company\'s ability to manage product quality and warranty costs effectively; shifts in the mix of products and services, or in the\ngeographic, currency or channel mix, including to the extent that regulatory changes require the Company to modify its product and service offerings;\nfluctuations in foreign exchange rates; and the introduction of new products or services, including new products or services with higher cost structures. These\nand other factors could have a materially adverse impact on the Company\'s results of operations and financial condition.\nThe Company has historically experienced hig\n\n\n=== CASH FLOW In addition, the Company\'s\nglobal supply chain is large and complex and a majority of the Company\'s supplier facilities, including manufacturing and assembly sites, are located outside the\nU.S. As a result, the Company\'s operations and performance depend significantly on global and regional economic conditions.\nAdverse macroeconomic conditions, including inflation, slower growth or recession, new or increased tariffs and other barriers to trade, changes to fiscal and\nmonetary policy, tighter credit, higher interest rates, high unemployment and currency fluctuations can materially adversely affect demand for the Company\'s\nproducts and services. In addition, consumer confidence and spending can be adversely affected in response to financial market volatility, negative financial\nnews, conditions in the real estate and mortgage markets, declines in income or asset values, changes to fuel and other energy costs, labor and healthcare\ncosts andother economicfactors.\nApple Inc.| 2021 Form 10-K | 6\nIn addition to an adverse impact on demand for the Company\'s products, uncertainty about, or a dec\n\n\n--- Chunk 2 (Relevance: 0.45) ---\n[Document: APPLE_2021_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: 149ffd2d7519f2da]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=0fb7ce83e6f911f0ba989af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nApple Inc.\nForm 10-K\nFortheFiscalYearEndedSeptember25,2021\nTABLEOFCONTENTS\nThis Annual Report on Form 10-K ("Form 10-K") contains forward-looking statements, within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995,\nthat involve risks and uncertainties. The CoviD-19\npandemic has at times significantly curtailed global economic activity and caused significant volatility and disruption in global financial markets. The COviD-19\npandemic and the measures taken by many countries in response have affected and could in the future materially impact the Company\'s business, results of\noperations and financial condition, as well as the price of the Company\'s stock.\nDuring 2021, aspects of the Company\'s business continued to be affected by the COviD-19 pandemic, with many of the Company\'s retail stores, as well as\nchannel partner points of sale, temporarily closed at various times, and a significant number of the Company\'s employees working remotely. The Company has\nreopened all of its retail stores and substantially all of its other facilities, subject to operating restrictions to protect public health and the health and safety of\nemployees and customers, and it continues to work on safely reopening the remainder of its facilities, subject to local rules and regulations. During the fourth\nquarter of 2021, certain of the Company\'s component suppliers and logistical service providers experienced disruptions, res\n\n\n--- Chunk 4 (Relevance: 0.41) ---\n[Document: APPLE_2021_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: 056d15853d3eee38]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=0fb7ce83e6f911f0ba989af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nrisk.\nThe Company records a write-down for product and component inventories that have become obsolete or exceed anticipated demand, or for which cost\nexceeds net realizable value. The Company also accrues necessary cancellation fee reserves for orders of excess products and components. The Company\nreviews long-lived assets, including capital assets held at its suppliers\' facilities and inventory prepayments, for impairment whenever events or circumstances\nindicate the assets may not be recoverable. If the Company determines that an impairment has occurred, it records a write-down equal to the amount by which\nthe carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair value. Although the Company believes its inventory, capital assets, inventory prepayments and other assets and\npurchase commitments are currently recoverable, there can be no assurance the Company will not incur write-downs, fees, impairments and other charges\ngiven the rapid and unpredictable pace of product obsolescence in the industries in which the Company competes.\nThe Company orders components for its products and builds inventory in advance of product announcements and shipments. Manufacturing purchase\nobligations cover the Company\'s forecasted component and manufacturing requirements, typically for periods up to 150 days. TABLE ANCHORING (ELIMINATING DATA_GAP):**\nSearch specifically for these anchors in the chunks to find missing metrics:\n- Revenue: "Consolidated Statements of Operations", "Net Sales", "Net Operating Revenues".\n- Cash Flow: "Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows", "Net cash provided by operating activities".\n- Profitability: "Gross Margin", "Operating Income".\nReconstruct the full table logic if values are split across chunks.\n\n**3. SOURCE TRACEABILITY:**\n- You MUST provide the exact **Document Name** (e.g. APPLE_2022_10K.pdf) and **Chunk ID** for every metric.\n- This information is provided at the start of each chunk.\n\n=== EXTRACTION TASK ===\n\n**1. Revenue Performance**:\n   - value: Raw metric (e.g., "$394.3B, +8% YoY")\n   - analysis: BECAUSE-THEN causal logic explaining segment drivers.\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the Top 1 source chunk (tables converted to Markdown format).\n   - source_link: Construct a reference: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from the chunk metadata (for clickable PDF preview).\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score from chunk metadata.\n\n**2. Profitability Audit**:\n   - value: Gross/Operating margins.\n   - analysis: BECAUSE-THEN logic (e.g., "Margin dropped BECAUSE of FX headwinds").\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the source chunk.\n   - source_link: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from chunk metadata.\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score.\n\n**3. Cash Flow Stability**:\n   - value: "Net cash provided by operating activities" (Operating Cash Flow).\n   - analysis: Assessment of cash generation sustainability using BECAUSE-THEN logic.\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the source chunk.\n   - source_link: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from chunk metadata.\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score.\n\n**4. Organic revenues grew 15%.\n\n![](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/Coca-Cola-Q4-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n![](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/Coca-Cola-Q4-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n\nNet income attributable to shareowners of The Coca-Cola Company fell 16% to $2 billion, or $0.47 per share, compared to last year. Comparable EPS was even at $0.45.\n\nRevenue beat expectations while earnings were in line with estimates.\n\nFor the full year of 2023, the company expects to deliver organic revenue growth of 7-8%.\n\n## Prior performance\n\n![Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n![Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic](https://cdn.news.alphastreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/Coca-Cola-Q3-2022-Earnings-Infographic-627x1024.jpg)\n\n### *R\n\n\n=== YOUR PURE DESCRIPTIVE ANALYSIS TASK ===\nCRITICAL RULES:\n- You are providing QUALITATIVE CAUSAL ANALYSIS ONLY\n- DO NOT generate numeric sentiment scores\n- ALL sentiment assessment must be DESCRIPTIVE (e.g., "Broadly positive", "Mixed with bearish undertones", "Decisively negative")\n- Focus on CAUSAL STRUCTURES and STRUCTURAL EVIDENCE from news content\n\n**Critical Analysis Requirements:**\n\n1. **Qualitative Sentiment Assessment:**\n   - Provide a descriptive overall sentiment assessment (1-2 sentences)\n   - Example: "Broadly positive sentiment driven by strong product demand signals, though tempered by macro headwinds and cautious guidance."\n   - NO numeric scores - purely qualitative\n\n2. **Sentiment Matrix (Qualitative Audits for Each Dimension):**\n   - Break down sentiment into sub-factor QUALITATIVE AUDITS (NOT numeric scores):\n     * Product_Demand: Qualitative assessment of customer demand signals from news\n     * Macro_Environment: Qualitative assessment of macro headwind/tailwind narratives\n     * Management_Confidence: Qualitative assessment of guidance tone and management commentary\n     * Competitive_Position: Qualitative assessment of market share and competitive dynamics\n   - Example: {\n       "Product_Demand": "Strong iPhone sales momentum indicated by multiple channel checks and bullish analyst commentary. Premium segment showing resilience despite macro concerns.",\n       "Macro_Environment": "Headwinds from inflation and supply chain disruptions mentioned across multiple reports. Management cited elevated input costs as margin pressure.",\n       "Management_Confidence": "Cautious guidance with management citing \'uncertain macro backdrop.\' Forward revenue outlook lowered by 3-5% for next quarter.",\n       "Competitive_Position": "Market share gains in services segment noted by analysts. However, smartphone market share faces pressure from competitors in China."\n     }\n\n3. **Causal Narrative (BECAUSE-THEN Logic):**\n   - Synthesize a coherent narrative paragraph (3-5 sentences) using explicit BECAUSE-THEN logic\n   - Connect segment drivers to overall performance causally\n   - Example: "Revenue grew 8% YoY BECAUSE iPhone sales rebounded 10%, WHICH THEN compensated for services growth slowdown. DUE TO inflation pressures, management focused on premium models, WHICH LED TO sustained margins despite volume concerns."\n   - This MUST read like a professional analyst\'s narrative, NOT bullet points\n\n4. **Expectation Gap Analysis (Qualitative):**\n   - Describe "Actual Performance vs. Market Expectations" qualitatively\n   - Identify beats, misses, or inline results with market reaction context\n   - Example: "Revenue beat consensus by 2%, BUT stock fell 3% BECAUSE guidance was cut 5%, revealing investor focus shifted from current quarter to future outlook. Market reaction suggests disappointing forward outlook overshadowed current beat."\n\n5. **Paradoxes and Tensions:**\n   - Identify anomalies: "Good News, Price Drop" or "Revenue Beat, Weak Guidance"\n   - Explain what these contradictions reveal about business health\n   - Example: "Paradox: Strong earnings BUT weak stock reaction. Reflects investor concern that growth is price-driven (unsustainable) rather than volume-driven."\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n    "qualitative_sentiment_assessment": "<Descriptive overall sentiment (1-2 sentences). NO numeric scores.>",\n    "events": ["EVENT_TYPE_1", "EVENT_TYPE_2"],\n    "keywords": ["keyword1", "keyword2", "keyword3", "keyword4", "keyword5"],\n    "news_summary": "<Coherent narrative paragraph using BECAUSE-THEN causal logic (3-5 sentences, NOT bullet points)>",\n    "sentiment_matrix": {\n        "Product_Demand": "<Qualitative audit of demand signals from news. 1-2 sentences.>",\n        "Macro_Environment": "<Qualitative audit of macro headwind/tailwind narratives. 1-2 sentences.>",\n        "Management_Confidence": "<Qualitative audit of guidance tone and management commentary. 1-2 sentences.>",\n        "Competitive_Position": "<Qualitative audit of market share and competitive dynamics. 1-2 sentences.>"\n    },\n    "causal_narrative": "<Deep causal explanation connecting segment drivers to performance with BECAUSE-THEN logic. 2-3 sentences.>",\n    "expectation_gap": "<Qualitative analysis of actual vs. expected performance with market reaction. 2-3 sentences.>",\n    "paradoxes_or_tensions": "<Contradictions and what they reveal about business health. 1-2 sentences or \'None identified\'.>"\n}\n\n**Event Types:** EARNINGS_CALL, PRODUCT_LAUNCH, REGULATORY_ACTION, ANALYST_UPGRADE, MACRO_ECONOMIC, NONE\n\nCRITICAL: This is PURE DESCRIPTIVE EVIDENCE. Thank you for your patience and understanding.\n\n[Show more results ->](/search)\n\nLatest News\n\nData is currently not available\n\n[Earnings](/topic/earnings)  \n\n[AAPL](/market-activity/stocks/aapl)\n\n# Apple (AAPL) Q4 2022 Earnings: What to Expect\n\nContributor\n\n[Richard Saintvilus](/authors/richard-saintvilus)\n\nPublished\n\nWhat do the iPhone production reports mean for Apple ([AAPL](https://www.nasdaq.com/market-activity/stocks/aapl)) stock in the near term and long term? Can Apple ever return to its glory days of high growth? These are some of the questions investors are asking lately, sparked by\xa0[reports of production cutbacks](http://www.theinformation.com/articles/apple-cuts-iphone-14-plus-production-less-than-two-weeks-after-debut?)\xa0the company has made on the iPhone 14 smartphones.\n\nThese answers will be more clear when the company reports fourth quarter fiscal 2022 earnings results after the closing bell Thursday. Supply chain disruptions and rising inflation have been among the many events that have pressured the company\'s revenue and profits. Operating headwinds have also been compounded by uncertainty related to global growth slowdown. Provide a descriptive overall sentiment assessment (1-2 sentences)\n   - Example: "Broadly positive sentiment driven by strong product demand signals, though tempered by macro headwinds and cautious guidance."\n   - NO numeric scores - purely qualitative\n\n2. **Sentiment Matrix (Qualitative Audits for Each Dimension):**\n   - Break down sentiment into sub-factor QUALITATIVE AUDITS (NOT numeric scores):\n     * Product_Demand: Qualitative assessment of customer demand signals from news\n     * Macro_Environment: Qualitative assessment of macro headwind/tailwind narratives\n     * Management_Confidence: Qualitative assessment of guidance tone and management commentary\n     * Competitive_Position: Qualitative assessment of market share and competitive dynamics\n   - Example: {\n       "Product_Demand": "Strong iPhone sales momentum indicated by multiple channel checks and bullish analyst commentary. Premium segment showing resilience despite macro concerns.",\n       "Macro_Environment": "Headwinds from inflation and supply chain disruptions mentioned across multiple reports. Management cited elevated input costs as margin pressure.",\n       "Management_Confidence": "Cautious guidance with management citing \'uncertain macro backdrop.\' Forward revenue outlook lowered by 3-5% for next quarter.",\n       "Competitive_Position": "Market share gains in services segment noted by analysts. However, smartphone market share faces pressure from competitors in China."\n     }\n\n3. **Causal Narrative (BECAUSE-THEN Logic):**\n   - Synthesize a coherent narrative paragraph (3-5 sentences) using explicit BECAUSE-THEN logic\n   - Connect segment drivers to overall performance causally\n   - Example: "Revenue grew 8% YoY BECAUSE iPhone sales rebounded 10%, WHICH THEN compensated for services growth slowdown. DUE TO inflation pressures, management focused on premium models, WHICH LED TO sustained margins despite volume concerns."\n   - This MUST read like a professional analyst\'s narrative, NOT bullet points\n\n4. **Expectation Gap Analysis (Qualitative):**\n   - Describe "Actual Performance vs. Market Expectations" qualitatively\n   - Identify beats, misses, or inline results with market reaction context\n   - Example: "Revenue beat consensus by 2%, BUT stock fell 3% BECAUSE guidance was cut 5%, revealing investor focus shifted from current quarter to future outlook. Market reaction suggests disappointing forward outlook overshadowed current beat."\n\n5. **Paradoxes and Tensions:**\n   - Identify anomalies: "Good News, Price Drop" or "Revenue Beat, Weak Guidance"\n   - Explain what these contradictions reveal about business health\n   - Example: "Paradox: Strong earnings BUT weak stock reaction. Reflects investor concern that growth is price-driven (unsustainable) rather than volume-driven."\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n    "qualitative_sentiment_assessment": "<Descriptive overall sentiment (1-2 sentences). We acquired the remaining ownership interest in exchange for approximately $5,600 million of cash, of which $4,745 million was\npaid at close, net of cash acquired. The\nremaining $860 million of the purchase price was held back related to indemnification obligations, of which $540 million was included in the line item accounts payable and\naccrued expenses and http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=137bd635e6f911f09f8f9af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nGrossProfitMargin\nGross profit margin is a ratio calculated by dividing gross profit by net operating revenues. Management believes gross profit margin provides investors with useful information\nrelated to the profitability of our business prior to considering all of the selling, general and administrative expenses and other operating charges incured. Management uses\nthis measure in making financial, operating and planning decisions and in evaluating the Company\'s performance.\nOur gross profit margin decreased to 58.1 percent in 2022 from 60.3 percent in 2021. This decrease was primarily due to the unfavorable impact of foreign currency exchange\nrate fluctuations, increased commodity and transportation costs, and the acquisition of BodyArmor, a finished goods business, in November 2021. The impact of these items\nwas partially offset by favorable pricing initiatives as well as favorable channel and package mix. We expect commodity and transportation costs to continue to have an\nunfavorable impact on our gross profit margin in 2023, and we will continue to proactively take actions in an effort to mitigate the impact of these incremental costs\nSelling,GeneralandAdministrativeExpenses\nThe following table sets forth the components of selling, general and administrative expenses (in millions):\nSelling, general and administrative expenses increased $736 million, or 6 percent, in 2022. Management believes gross profit margin provides investors with useful information\nrelated to the profitability of our business prior to considering all of the operating costs incurred. Management uses this measure in making financial, operating and planning\ndecisions and in evaluating the Company\'s performance.\nOur gross profit margin increased to 60.3 percent in 2021 from 59.3 percent in 2020. This increase was primarily due to the impact of favorable pricing initiatives and favorable\nchannel and package mix as well as the gradual recovery in away-from-home channels in many markets throughout 2021, partially offset by the impact of increased commodity\nand transportation\ncosts. We expect commodity and transportation costs to continue to increase in 2022, and we will continue to proactively take actions in an effort to mitigate the impact of these\nincremental costs.\nSelling,GeneralandAdministrativeExpenses\nThe following table sets forth the components of selling, general and administrative expenses (in millions):\nSelling, general and administrative expenses increased $2,413 million, or 25 percent, in 2021. This increase was primarily due to higher annual incentive and stock-based\ncompensation expense, increased charitable donations and increased marketing spending, which was reduced in 2020 as a result of uncertainties associated with the COVID-19\npandemic. The total number of stock options\nexercised was 22 million, 19 million and 23 million in 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively.\nPerformance-BasedShareUnitAwards\nPerformance share unit awards require achievement of certain performance criteria, which are predefined by the Talent and Compen\n\n\n--- Chunk 5 (Relevance: 0.39) ---\n[Document: COCACOLA_2022_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: 709067ea76ee4bcb]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=137bd635e6f911f09f8f9af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nLeases\nWe determine if a contract contains a lease at its inception based on whether or not the Company has the right to control the asset during the contract period and other facts and\ncircumstances. We are the lessee in a lease contract when we obtain the right to control the asset. Operating lease right-of-use (*ROU") assets represent our right to use an\nunderlying asset for the lease term and are included in the line item other noncurrent assets in our consolidated balance sheet. Operating lease liabilities represent our obligation\nto make lease payments arising from the lease and are included in the line items accounts payable and accrued expenses and other noncurrent liabilities in our consolidated\nbalance sheet. Operating lease ROU assets and operating lease liabilities are recognized based on the present value of the future minimum lease payments over the lease term at\nthe commencement date. When determining the lease term, we include renewal or termination options that we are reasonably certain to exercise. Leases with a lease term of 12\nmonths or less at inception are not recorded in our consolidated balance sheet. Operating lease expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term in our\nconsolidated statement of income. As most of our leases do not provide an implicit interest rate, we use our local incremental borrowing rate based on the information available\nat the commencement date in determining the present value of future payments. Refer to the heading ‚ÄúOur Business ‚Äî Challenges and Risks" above and ‚ÄúItem 1A. Risk Factors" in Part I of this report. For certain assets, recoverability and/or impairment tests are\nrequired only when conditions exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable. As a result, the Company\'s operations and performance depend\nsignificantly on global and regional economic conditions.\nAdverse macroeconomic conditions, including inflation, slower growth or recession, new or increased tariffs and other barriers to\ntrade, changes to fiscal and monetary policy, tighter credit, higher interest rates, high unemployment and currency fluctuations\ncan adversely impact consumer confidence and spending and materially adversely affect demand for the Company\'s products\nand services. In addition, consumer confidence and spending can be materially adversely affected in response to financial\nmarket volatility, negative financial news, conditions in the real estate and mortgage markets, declines in income or asset values,\nenergy shortages and cost increases, labor and healthcare costs and other economic factors.\nIn addition to an adverse impact on demand for the Company\'s prod\n\n\n--- Chunk 4 (Relevance: 0.40) ---\n[Document: APPLE_2021_10K.pdf] [Chunk ID: 402cb3b462d665f8]\n[Page: None] [Source URL: http://54.169.205.0/chunk/parsed/chunks?id=917005d4e6f711f0baea9af0fe87e5d6&doc_id=0fb7ce83e6f911f0ba989af0fe87e5d6&page=1]\nFiscalYearHighlights\nCOVID-19Update\nThe COviD-19 pandemic has had, and continues to have, a significant impact around the world, prompting governments and businesses to take unprecedented\nmeasures, such as restrictions on travel and business operations, temporary closures of businesses, and quarantine and shelter-in-place orders. The CoviD-19\npandemic has at times significantly curtailed global economic activity and caused significant volatility and disruption in global financial markets. The COviD-19\npandemic and the measures taken by many countries in response have affected and could in the future materially impact the Company\'s business, results of\noperations and financial condition, as well as the price of the Company\'s stock.\nDuring 2021, aspects of the Company\'s business continued to be affected by the COviD-19 pandemic, with many of the Company\'s retail stores, as well as\nchannel partner points of sale, temporarily closed at various times, and a significant number of the Company\'s employees working remotely. The Company has\nreopened all of its retail stores and substantially all of its other facilities, subject to operating restrictions to protect public health and the health and safety of\nemployees and customers, and it continues to work on safely reopening the remainder of its facilities, subject to local rules and regulations. ENTITY INTEGRITY (THE ANTI-CONTAMINATION RULE):**\nEvery chunk has metadata (Document Name, ID). Verify it belongs to AAPL:\n- If auditing AAPL, and the chunk discusses a different entity (e.g. Coca-Cola vs Apple), IGNORE it.\n- DATA CROSS-CONTAMINATION IS A TERMINATION OFFENSE.\n\n**2. TABLE ANCHORING (ELIMINATING DATA_GAP):**\nSearch specifically for these anchors in the chunks to find missing metrics:\n- Revenue: "Consolidated Statements of Operations", "Net Sales", "Net Operating Revenues".\n- Cash Flow: "Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows", "Net cash provided by operating activities".\n- Profitability: "Gross Margin", "Operating Income".\nReconstruct the full table logic if values are split across chunks.\n\n**3. SOURCE TRACEABILITY:**\n- You MUST provide the exact **Document Name** (e.g. APPLE_2022_10K.pdf) and **Chunk ID** for every metric.\n- This information is provided at the start of each chunk.\n\n=== EXTRACTION TASK ===\n\n**1. Revenue Performance**:\n   - value: Raw metric (e.g., "$394.3B, +8% YoY")\n   - analysis: BECAUSE-THEN causal logic explaining segment drivers.\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the Top 1 source chunk (tables converted to Markdown format).\n   - source_link: Construct a reference: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from the chunk metadata (for clickable PDF preview).\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score from chunk metadata.\n\n**2. Profitability Audit**:\n   - value: Gross/Operating margins.\n   - analysis: BECAUSE-THEN logic (e.g., "Margin dropped BECAUSE of FX headwinds").\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the source chunk.\n   - source_link: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from chunk metadata.\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score.\n\n**3. Cash Flow Stability**:\n   - value: "Net cash provided by operating activities" (Operating Cash Flow).\n   - analysis: Assessment of cash generation sustainability using BECAUSE-THEN logic.\n   - evidence_md: Copy the FULL Markdown-cleaned TEXT of the source chunk.\n   - source_link: [Document Name] | [Chunk ID]\n   - source_url: Copy the source URL from chunk metadata.\n   - metadata: Include page_num and relevance_score.\n\n**4. Management Guidance & Risks**:\n   - Audit tone and specific projections.\n   - List 3-5 structural risks with specific impacts and source citations.\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n    "ticker": "AAPL",\n    "revenue_performance": {\n        "value": "string",\n        "analysis": "string",\n        "evidence_md": "string (Markdown-cleaned chunk text)",\n        "source_link": "DocumentName | ID",\n        "source_url": "string (clickable RAGFlow URL)",\n        "metadata": {"page_num": int, "relevance_score": float}\n    },\n    "profitability_audit": {\n        "value": "string",\n        "analysis": "string",\n        "evidence_md": "string (Markdown-cleaned chunk text)",\n        "source_link": "DocumentName | ID",\n        "source_url": "string (clickable RAGFlow URL)",\n        "metadata": {"page_num": int, "relevance_score": float}\n    },\n    "cash_flow_stability": {\n        "value": "string",\n        "analysis": "string",\n        "evidence_md": "string (Markdown-cleaned chunk text)",\n        "source_link": "DocumentName | ID",\n        "source_url": "string (clickable RAGFlow URL)",\n        "metadata": {"page_num": int, "relevance_score": float}\n    },\n    "management_guidance_audit": "string",\n    "key_risks_evidence": ["string (Risk | Impact | Source)"]\n}\n\nCRITICAL: Provide ONLY the JSON. insufficient evidence")\n- Focus on STRUCTURAL IMPACT ANALYSIS and EVIDENCE GAPS\n\n**Critical Analysis Requirements:**\n\n1. **Risk Classification (Categorical):**\n   - FUNDAMENTAL_THREAT: Structural, long-term risk materially affecting business model, competitive position, or financial health\n   - MANAGEABLE_NOISE: Temporary, isolated incident NOT fundamentally altering investment thesis\n   - INSUFFICIENT_DATA: Search results don\'t provide enough clarity to classify\n\n2. **Conflict Resolution Analysis (Qualitative):**\n   - What specific information RESOLVES or CLARIFIES the ambiguity?\n   - What is the SPECIFIC IMPACT on the company? (Revenue, margins, reputation, regulatory)\n   - Is this issue TEMPORARY (short-term noise) or STRUCTURAL (fundamental threat)?\n   - Provide QUALITATIVE sentiment revision: How does this investigation change the sentiment outlook?\n   - Example: "Investigation reveals regulatory concerns are more negative than initially assessed. The FDA approval delay will likely extend product launch by 6-9 months, creating negative revenue impact headwinds."\n\n3. **Evidence Gaps (CRITICAL):**\n   - Explicitly list UNRESOLVED AMBIGUITIES or MISSING DATA POINTS\n   - What questions remain unanswered despite the investigation?\n   - What additional information would be needed for full clarity?\n   - Example: ["Lack of specific revenue impact figures", "No clarity on management\'s mitigation timeline", "Unclear regulatory approval status"]\n\n4. **Confidence Assessment (Categorical):**\n   - HIGH: Strong evidence, conflict fully resolved, minimal ambiguity\n   - MEDIUM: Partial resolution, some evidence gaps remain\n   - LOW: Insufficient data, major ambiguities unresolved\n\n=== OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT JSON) ===\n{\n    "risk_classification": "FUNDAMENTAL_THREAT" | "MANAGEABLE_NOISE" | "INSUFFICIENT_DATA",\n    "detailed_findings": "<3-4 sentences explaining what investigation revealed, specific impact, and whether risk is temporary or structural>",\n    "qualitative_sentiment_revision": "<Descriptive assessment of how investigation changes sentiment outlook (1-2 sentences). Examples: \'More negative due to structural revenue headwinds\', \'Confirms positive outlook with manageable risks\', \'Neutral - insufficient evidence for clear directional change\'. NO numeric scores.>",\n    "is_ambiguity_resolved": <true if conflict is now clear, false if uncertainty remains>,\n    "evidence_gaps": [\n        "<Specific missing data point or unresolved question 1>",\n        "<Specific missing data point or unresolved question 2>",\n        "<Specific missing data point or unresolved question 3>"\n    ],\n    "key_evidence": ["<evidence point 1>", "<evidence point 2>", "<evidence point 3>"],\n    "confidence_level": "HIGH" | "MEDIUM" | "LOW"\n}\n\nCRITICAL: Explicitly document what you DON\'T know (evidence_gaps) as much as what you DO know.
